content.body: iwan.aucamp: there have been a few attempts, see the issues; none has really made it to the point where it would seem like a clear improvement, at least to me
content.formatted_body: iwan.aucamp: there have been a few attempts, see the issues; none has really made it to the point where it would seem like a clear improvement, at least to me

content.body: A clear improvement as compared to not having one, or as compared to the IETF grammar?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: A clear improvement as compared to not having one, or as compared to the IETF grammar?

content.body: It seems to me that if the intent is indeed to obsolete RFC 3986 then a providing a grammar would be an essential part of it.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: It seems to me that if the intent is indeed to obsolete RFC 3986 then a providing a grammar would be an essential part of it.

content.body: I see for example mention in the one issue that it would be simple, but if it  would be, why not just make it?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I see for example mention in the one issue that it would be simple, but if it  would be, why not just make it?

content.body: Not all assertions on the internet happen to be true. ðŸ™‚ Likewise, you might find that not everyone is as convinced about the merit of grammars.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Not all assertions on the internet happen to be true. ðŸ™‚ Likewise, you might find that not everyone is as convinced about the merit of grammars.

content.body: Okay, but say I want to incorporate it into another format, like Turtle?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Okay, but say I want to incorporate it into another format, like Turtle?

content.body: iwan.aucamp: in most cases you wouldn't want that grammar to fall over the moment this grammar is extended in some way, so usually you'd have a somewhat broader field and then define processing requirements around it
content.formatted_body: iwan.aucamp: in most cases you wouldn't want that grammar to fall over the moment this grammar is extended in some way, so usually you'd have a somewhat broader field and then define processing requirements around it

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: iwan.aucamp: in most cases you wouldn't want that grammar to fall over the moment this grammar is extended in some way, so usually you'd have a somewhat broader field and then define processing requirements around it

iwan.aucamp: in most cases you wouldn't want that grammar to fall over the moment this grammar is extended in some way, so usually you'd have a somewhat broader field and then define processing requirements around it

content.body: (This is one of the criticisms against grammar, it alone is not sufficient to define what you actually expect to happen)
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: (This is one of the criticisms against grammar, it alone is not sufficient to define what you actually expect to happen)

content.body: foolip: I suppose we want to list webidl2.js as a place to file issues on when Web IDL gets changed (that would involve two minor changes to whatwg/spec-factory and whatwg/meta), but maybe other tools as well? E.g., bikeshed?
content.formatted_body: foolip: I suppose we want to list webidl2.js as a place to file issues on when Web IDL gets changed (that would involve two minor changes to whatwg/spec-factory and whatwg/meta), but maybe other tools as well? E.g., bikeshed?

content.body:
> <@annevk:mozilla.org> foolip: so does idlharness.js not use webidl2.js underneath?

It does, it's just that it's completely manual to update the dependency. Perhaps it would be good to get a CI job for that
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @annevk:mozilla.org
foolip: so does idlharness.js not use webidl2.js underneath?
It does, it's just that it's completely manual to update the dependency. Perhaps it would be good to get a CI job for that
